This sudden change led to a significant increase in grey rot on the ripening Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier grapes. The harvest was fast-paced and completed very quickly, demanding precise and methodical selection work, of an unprecedented level even for Roederer. The harvest took place from 31 August to 9 September 2017. A third each from the Vallée de la Marne, the Côte des Blancs and the Montagne de Reims. 42% Chardonnay (the most successful variety in 2017), 36% Pinot Noir, 22% Pinot Meunier. Only 34% went through malo.' Dosage is 8 g/l (whereas Brut Premier used to be 9 g/l).
"Deep straw colour and tiny, tiny bead. Really satisfying, complete, beautifully balanced nose with some evolution and richness. A little bit of toastiness and it tastes pretty ripe. Very different indeed from a Brut Zéro champagne! Firm. Some tasters may object to the dosage. But it's a beautiful wine."”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “The new climate and era have made Louis Roederer replace its Brut Premier with Collection. The new cuvée’s resilience derives from the “perpetual reserve” (Réserve perpétuelle) of previous vintages. In the challenging 2017 vintage, Chardonnay was made to play an important role. The result is rich with fine depth. It comes with nicely toasted, ripe fruity aroma with vanilla, lemon and hazelnut. The taste is softly lush but fresh and elegantly layered.”

reviews.author: Anne Krebiehl MW
reviews.note: “The nose is a trio of Mirabelle plum, salted shortbread and freshly-cut yellow apple flesh, suggesting ripest fruit. The palate immediately dials this impression back with vivid briskness and a lovely, salty edge along with the scant bitterness of the pillowy citrus pith you find on thick-skinned pink grapefruit. But there is roundness and generosity at the heart, beautiful depth and lively, fine, brisk mousse. That enticing and rather mouth-watering edge of bitterness re-emerges seductively on the finish.”

name: Louis Roederer Collection 242 - No Gift Box

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Stylish toast-complexed nose with plenty of fresh fruit, charred and gunpowdery notes. Fresh and succulent on the refined palate of fine fruit purity. Pristinely clean and full of fruit. Very long and comes with a perfectly balanced generous dosage. Elegant, light style but with emerging depth. Benefits from one to three years on cork. Recently tasted from a several years' old jeroboam and the wine was simply stunning.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “This lightly Chardonnay-driven blend benefits from some 30% of reserve wines from the previous two harvests. Pale lemon-green colour. The lovely, fragrant sweetly fruity nose has ripe pear, crunchy red apple and zingy lemon. The palate is light and refreshing, but with a lovely fruit purity and intensity. Lingering silky palate and classy, creamy mousse. There is a lovely easiness and quaffing character to this. Dosage 9g/l”

reviews.author: Stephan Reinhardt
reviews.note: “Taittinger's NV Brut Reserve—a blend of more than 35 different vineyards, assembling 40% Chardonnay, 35% Pinot Noir and 25% Pinot Meunier, including 30% reserve wines—has a clear, fresh and vinous bouquet with Pinot Meunier flavors in front. Bottled in 2014 and disgorged in March 2017 with nine grams of dosage, this is a lithe and fresh but mouth-filling Brut with round and aromatic fruit. It tastes almost as charming as the Rosé Prestige yet less vinous and is rather lean and fresh. Tasted in November 2017.”

reviews.author: Nick Baker
reviews.note: “Particularly fine and strong stream of bubbles with lots of lemon and lime notes and hints of tropical fruits like guava and pineapple and some creaminess that you don't often see in these non vintage champagnes. Nice and dry and lingering. Lovely today on a hot London day. This current cuvee must have its core part of the blend from one of the great vintages like 2010. Wish this was declared on the label.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Tasted blind. Overall score placed it fourth out of 12 wines. Light straw. Sweetish nose – one of the few! Candied violets on the nose. Light and off dry. Quite chunky, lime-marmalade impression. Not much undertow. Good texture and refreshment value on the finish. A little chew on the end. Lots of acidity underneath. ”

reviews.author: Tom Hewson
reviews.note: “The style of Piper brut is friendly, approachable and zesty, one of the more reliable widely available Grandes Marques NV wines lately. It's all about the play between bright yellow citrus zest – that Sézannais Chardonnay singing loudly? – playing with some sparky reductive grillé flourishes and just enough fleshy Pinot fruit, nougat and almond stuffing to support it. Impressive for a base year as tricky as 2017, so we might expect even more of 2018 and 2019 to come. Full of life!”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Piper-Heidsieck's Brut is one of the most red grape-dominant grande marque non-vintages, with the broad blend of 50% Pinot Noir bringing depth, body and delicious spicy and toasty layers. Lemon-green in colour. The inviting nose has creamy fruit, strawberry, blood orange, dried flowers, baking spices and crunchy red apple. A fine toastiness emerges stronger with time in the glass. Friendly, fleshy and round lightweight palate. This will also reward further cellaring. Sublime in magnum. Dosage 8g/l”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Medium-deep lemon colour. Stylish, toasty and leesy nose. Lovely gunpowdery touch. Rather sweet palate but still in balance. Long, linear, succulent, finely focused palate. Super-stylish. This champagne has improved tremendously over the last years. Now it can sometimes challenge even Charles Heidsieck Brut Réserve. Outstanding in magnum.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “This Henriot classic is a blend from 12 villages. Le Mesnil-sur-Oger, Chouilly and Avize play an important role, but there are also grapes from outside the Côte des Blancs - Trépail, Montgueux and Vitryat - enriching the blend. The overt nose is beautifully toasty, with soft vanilla notes combining to toasted bread, lemon curd, lime peel and green apple. The creamy palate comes with a cushiony mousse and a zingy, driven acid line leading to a gunpowdery mineral finish. Complexity and richness meeting invigorating freshness. Dosage <8g/l”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “The latest rendition of Henriot's NV Blanc de Blancs is showing well, opening in the glass with notes of nectarine, citrus oil, toasted bread and light reduction. Medium to full-bodied, fleshy and enveloping, with a generous core of fruit, lively acids and a pretty pinpoint mousse, it concludes with a saline finish. This is a comparatively rich iteration of this cuvée, and it should pick up additional complexity with age.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Pale greenish straw. Powerfully aromatic and then bracingly crisp – actually quite surprisingly in view of the rather evolved nose. A real wake-up call of a wine with a certain electric minerality. Bone dry. Very much a superior aperitif style. Seriously zesty – lime zest? But it's admirably long. And the mousse is well judged. Young winemaker Alice Tétienne presented this online with impressive conviction.”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “Based on the 2015 vintage, the new release of Henriot's NV Blanc de Blancs bursts with expressive aromas of white peach, tangerine, sweet orchard fruit and freshly baked bread. Medium to full-bodied, pillowy and nicely concentrated, with tangy acids and a pearly mousse, this new disgorgement is showing particularly well.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Magnum. Intense lemon yellow colour. Really quite mature, candified nose yet with marked citrus acidity on the palate. It tastes more marked by Chardonnay than by Pinot. Zesty and refreshing. Medium finish that does build to quite a sweet note on the very end, but it's perhaps just a little too austere at this point to be truly seductive. Drink 2022-34”

name: Charles Heidsieck Coteaux Champenois Ambonnay Rouge - Trio Case

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Laurent-Perrier is launching a new and improved version of its iconic non-vintage Brut L-P. La Cuvée is the result of 15 years of development, which has meant an increasing number of villages entering the cuvée. The first blend is a mix of 2012 and 2009 vintages, both excellent years. The style is very much as before but one can sense an increased layer of depth and smooth richness. What is most laudable is the impeccable harmony the wine possesses already upon release. Such a pleasurable, round and energetic champagne. ”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Smoky reductive nose with real depth and lively age. Serious champagne, though at the full price it's quite expensive. ”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “This is the new and improved version of the house's previous non-vintage, Brut LP, first released in 2017. The elegantly floral, sensuous nose of lemon and orchard fruit has a light toasty whiff, alongside a touch of cardamom spiciness. Even lovely yeasty complexity is coming through. The palate is seamless and silky, very fine, with this flowing sensation enhancing the quaffing character. A drinkable, charming even if lightweight wine, with laudable fruit purity and impeccable balance.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Laurent-Perrier is launching a new and improved version of its iconic non-vintage Brut L-P. reviews.author: Richard Hemming MW
reviews.note: “'La Cuvée' is a rebrand for their non-vintage, I gather. There’s a lot of savoury umami character on the nose and chewy green citrus fruit. Long and fragrant to finish. (RH)”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“80% of the grapes for this prettily packaged wine come from premier or grand cru villages. The blend is 90% Pinot Noir (including 8% still red from the Meurtet vineyard on the hill directly behind the winery in Aÿ) and 10% Chardonnay. After the blend is made it spends three years ageing on the lees, and a further six months following disgorgement with a dosage of 9 g/l. Note that the word Sakura, Japanese for cherry blossom, doesn't appear on either front or back label, although it is on the pink box in which the bottle is packaged. And there are no details of date of disgorgement or of the vintages in the blend. Numbers on the foil: 124776 and LA121D30919.
Extremely pale orangey smoked-salmon colour. Quite a broad nose reminiscent of buttery apple sauce. Marked acidity – much more than you would expect from the nose – but mouth-filling, with gentle mousse and still a little bite on the finish. You could drink this with or without food. A useful Valentine champagne?
Drink 2021 – 2023”

name: Barons de Rothschild Blanc de Blancs

reviews.author: Antonio Galloni
reviews.note: “The 2008 Blanc de Blancs Cuvée Speciale is a blend of fruit from Le Mesnil-sur-Oger, Oger, Avize and Cramant. Deep, resonant and beautifully layered in the glass, the 2008 is super-impressive. I especially admire the way the wine fleshes out with a bit of air. Citrus, sage, menthol and dried flowers add nuance to what is a very powerful wine. The 2008 saw full malolactic fermentation, with some bâtonnage for added texture. This is a superb showing from the Rothschild family.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Medium-deep lemon colour. Fresh, gently toasty, strongly lemony nose. Cream, roasted nuts and white flowers. Zesty, linear palate. Balanced, energisingly sharp but comes with innate charm.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Pronounced toasty-mineral nose with confectionary-style sweetness of fruit of tropical fruit, marmalade, cardamom and candied tones.Very clean fruitiness and ample, balanced dosage. Fresh and salivating. Soft and silky, refined palate. A fine, solid, stylish non-vintage where the quality of the grapes (2/3 grand cru!) and impact of reserve wines (30%, 1-5 year-old + a touch of top blanc de blancs from their perpetual cuvée). Divine in magnum, 90 points and up. The base year for bottles sold at the end of 2016 was 2012.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Representing a snapshot of the Henriot grape sourcing, the core of this broad blend is in Côte des Blancs Chardonnay, with Pinot Noir from the Montagne de Reims supporting and Meunier playing a minor role (5%). There's a lovely complexity building up already on the nose: coffee-laden toastiness alongside sweet fruity notes, even of the tropical kind. Yellow apple, yellow plums and lemon juice. The intense palate is bursting with pristine fruit, the silky-smooth palate refreshed by perky acidity. Long, lingering finish of deliciousness. Dosage <8g/l”

reviews.author: Richard Hemming MW
reviews.note: “Lovely milky nose with sweet coffee and rich pastry aromas. Rich apple fruit on the palate and a soft, smooth palate that finishes with a smoky, flinty persistence. Precise, rounded, classic.”

reviews.author: Josh Reynolds
reviews.note: “Light gold. Lees-accented orchard and citrus fruit aromas are complicated by sweet butter, iodine and smoky minerals. Dry and expansive on the palate, offering lively pear and melon flavors and a refreshingly bitter touch of orange pith. Ample but lithe brut, with very good finishing punch and repeating smoke and pear qualities.”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “Based on the 2015 vintage, the latest release of Henriot's NV Brut Souverain offers up inviting aromas of white peach, apple blossom, nectarine and pastry cream. Medium-bodied, bright and fleshy, with a pretty core of fruit, tangy acids and a pillowy mousse, it's drinking well on release.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Honeyed straw colour. Tingly, vibrant nose with great energy even if without a massively deep undertow. Real grip and presence on the palate. And impressive persistence. But it's a sprightly wine rather than one in which pronounced autolysis has been sought.”

reviews.author: Tamlyn Currin
reviews.note:
“50–55% Chardonnay, 35–40% Pinot Noir, 10–15% Pinot Meunier. 25–35% reserve wines. Bottles spend three to four years on lees, magnums five to six years. Dosage 8 g/l. Date on label suggests it may have been disgorged 8 May 2017.
Mid lemon colour. Lemon-brioche nose. Much more low-key fizz than the Rosé. Just a suggestion of bubbles, despite a huge froth-up when the wine was poured. Chalky, chewy, lemon-zested palate. Spiky and angled – makes you hungry just to sip it. Proper appetite whetter. Bring on the oysters! (Or fish and chips…?) (TC)”

reviews.author: Anne Krebiehl MW
reviews.note: “Notes of both Golden Delicious and Granny Smith apples fill the nose with their respective ripeness and freshness. The palate is slender, almost delicate, and vivid with the fresher rather than the riper apple notes. The mousse is fine and lively, supporting and underlining the fruit-driven yet-elegant style of this wine. The wood influence is beyond subtle and beautifully handled. An ideal, understated and refreshing aperitif.”

reviews.author: Josh Reynolds
reviews.note: “Bright yellow-gold. Ripe orange, poached pear and vanilla on the deeply perfumed nose. Fleshy and open-knit, offering pliant orchard and pit fruit flavors braced and lifted by juicy acidity. At once rich and lively, with the vanilla note repeating on the smooth, toasty finish. Just over one-third of this blend is barrel-fermented reserve wine.”

reviews.author: Claire Nesbitt
reviews.note: “Attractive nose of caramelised apples, dried apricots, pastries, shortbread, praline and some roasted vanilla bean. Some saline notes, too. Medium-to full-bodied with bright acidity and silky bubbles. Sleek and well integrated.”

reviews.author: Roger Voss
reviews.note: “The five years of aging in bottle and the 40% reserve wine have given this rich blend of Pinot Noir and Champagne great balance as well as intensity and ripeness. The wine is ready to drink.”

reviews.author: Tom Hewson
reviews.note: “Essentiel is the same wine as the Brut, but with extra ageing on lees and a lower dosage (future editions, however, will be bespoke blends). So, 50% Pinot Noir, 30% Pinot Meunier and 20% Chardonnay, based on 2014 in this case. Over the Brut you notice an uplift in ground nut and praline richness, the fruit turning candied and a little spice emerging. It's still that classic sparky, zesty Piper style at heart, just with a touch of umami length and interest. Highly recommendable ”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “Based on the 2016 vintage and disgorged in April 2021 with six grams per liter dosage, the NV Extra-Brut Blanc de Blancs Essentiel exhibits attractive aromas of crisp orchard fruit, buttered toast, dried white flowers and fresh herbs. Medium-bodied, taut and incisive, it's still so shut down from its recent disgorgement that it's hard to get a firm sense of its ultimate quality. However, the basis for complexity, balance and interest appears to be present.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Developing colour. The come-hither nose is gorgeously complex and comes with sweet toasty and bisquity richness. An appetising mix of vanilla, spices, and ample red fruit of apple and strawberry. Rich and structured on the palate, plentiful but comes with lovely succulence. ”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “This wine is a broad blend, including Chardonnays from the Côte des Blancs, the Montagne de Reims and the Sézannais. Bright, lemon-green colour. Based on the 2016 vintage, with 30% of reserve wines, this comes with a finely detailed toasty-lemony nose. The nose has crunchy fruit with mineral and gunpowder undertones. Brisk acidity on the linear extra-brut palate, which comes with energetic drive and a prickly, vibrant mousse. The best of the Essentiel Blanc de Blancs editions so far. Disgorged 4/21; dosage 6g/l”

reviews.author: James Suckling
reviews.note: “This has aromas of apricots, white strawberries, peach pits, almonds and pastries. Creamy and balanced, medium-bodied, with silky bubbles and a nicely savoury and dry finish. Based on 2018 vintage. 44% pinot noir, 34% meunier and 22% chardonnay. 4g/L dosage.”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “Based on the 2015 vintage, the NV Extra-Brut Essentiel is a Pinot Noir-dominant blend complemented by some 20% reserve wines that was disgorged in May 2020 with five grams per liter dosage. Offering up aromas of golden orchard fruit, freshly baked bread and warm biscuits, it's medium to full-bodied, with a pillowy mousse, brisk acids and a mouthwatering finish. This will benefit from another year on cork to knit together and round out, but it's a creditable effort.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Stylish toast-complexed nose with plenty of fresh fruit, charred and gunpowdery notes. Fresh and succulent on the refined palate of fine fruit purity. reviews.note: “The latest release of Delamotte's NV Brut is especially charming, bursting with aromas of crisp orchard fruit, peach and freshly baked bread. Medium to full-bodied, pillowy and enveloping, it's a fleshy, giving wine that's ample and pliant, with a pinpoint mousse and a nicely defined finish.”

reviews.author: James Suckling
reviews.note: “Quite impressive richness and gently toasty aromas on the nose here with almond, savory and sweet, bready autolysis notes. The palate has a fresh, succulent and smooth feel with soft, citrusy fruit flesh. Holds long. Drink now.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “The purely fruity, classily withdrawing nose gives off lovely reductive gunpowdery and smoky whiffs. The fruit is mainly on the white-fruit side, with lemon, mirabelle plums and sweet peach contributing. The palate is silky but airy, with a lovely friendliness to it all. This is a great-value, quaffable Champagne, but it's by no means boring. The secret here is the 90% grand cru fruit. Dosage 8g/l”

name: Pierre Gimonnet et Fils Millesime de Collection Vieilles Vignes de Chardonnay

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “Released only in magnum, the 2008 Brut Millésime de Collection Vieilles Vignes is the same wine as Gimonnet's Special Club, bit it sees more than 10 years sur lattes before disgorgement. Unwinding in the glass with a deep and complex bouquet of pear, green apple, citrus zest, oyster shell, smoke and pastry cream, it's full-bodied, chalky and incisive, with terrific depth at the core, promising reserve and a long, resonant finish.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“Really serious wine with a beginning, middle and end. Lovely balance between serious and hedonistic. Complete. Drink 2025 – 2029
”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Fairly wet summer but saved by a fine September. Deep honeyed gold. Clearly fully mature with a deep, resonant, somehow mineral/burnished metal nose. Very serious. A rich start but a super-appetising dry finish. Complex with a note of lime and yet richness too. Utterly beguiling. Long. Just the right amount of appetising mousse.”

name: Pierre Gimonnet et Fils Cuis 1er Cru

reviews.author: Antonio Galloni
reviews.note: “The NV Brut Blanc de Blancs Cuis 1er Cru is loaded with intense saline, mineral and savory inflections that play off the lemon and grapefruit flavors. Taut and nervy, with striking tension, the 1er Cru hits all the right notes. I love the energy here. Disgorged: November 15, 2019.”

reviews.author: Antonio Galloni
reviews.note: “he NV Blanc de Blancs Cuis 1er Cru is such a classic Gimonnet wine. Light on its feet and gracious, with soaring aromatics and tons of nuance, the 1er Cru is a winner. Bright floral overtones, citrus, brioche and apple are some of the many notes that are delineated in the glass. Among the entry-level wines in this range, the Cuis 1er Cru offers the best expression of the Gimonnet style at an affordable price. I loved it. Disgorged: March 16, 2019.”

reviews.note: “Pronounced toasty-mineral nose with confectionary-style sweetness of fruit of tropical fruit, marmalade, cardamom and candied tones.Very clean fruitiness and ample, balanced dosage. reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “With the lion's share of Palmer's 350 growers' vineyards being located on the Montagne de Reims, its fruit forms the core of this broad blend. The rest of the grapes come from Côte de Sézanne and Côte des Bar. Bright lemon in colour, with some depth. The overall note is charmingly, sweetly fruity, with an impeccable ground coffee tone adding layers. A complex mix of yellow and red fruit, but there is also a dark spiciness giving an element of interest. The palate is generous, with an age-mellowed velvety texture. However, the overall feeling remains light due to a super-stylish acid line. A remarkable-value non-vintage in an age-complexed, radiantly fruity and luxuriously toasty style. Dosage 7g/l”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Complex, classy toast-lead nose. Plenty of pristine fruit, cream, vanilla, peach, marshmallow and candy. Soft, velvety palate with a fine mousse. Lively, playful, dancing palate with a lovely acid line. Long-lasting, pure, fruity finish. Compact and complete. Perfectly crafted and finely polished. Worth 93p in magnum in a great year such as the 2008 and 2013 based cuvées. ”

reviews.author: William Kelley
reviews.note: “The latest rendition of Palmer's NV Brut Réserve is quite reserved out of the gates, unwinding with notes of crisp orchard fruit, citrus zest and fresh bread. Medium to full-bodied, taut and tangy, with bracing acids and a pinpoint mousse, it's not quite as generous as its immediate predecessors have been.”

reviews.author: Anne Krebiehl MW
reviews.note: “A wonderfully fresh nose presents notions of ripe lemon flesh and zest, along with stone fruit. The palate has a zesty edge. The mousse is a bit on the frothy side but the flavours are fruity and brisk. Very much an aperitif style, enlivening but balanced.”

reviews.author: Tom Hewson
reviews.note: “The style of Piper brut is friendly, approachable and zesty, one of the more reliable widely available Grandes Marques NV wines lately. It's all about the play between bright yellow citrus zest – that Sézannais Chardonnay singing loudly? – playing with some sparky reductive grillé flourishes and just enough fleshy Pinot fruit, nougat and almond stuffing to support it. Impressive for a base year as tricky as 2017, so we might expect even more of 2018 and 2019 to come. Full of life!”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Piper-Heidsieck's Brut is one of the most red grape-dominant grande marque non-vintages, with the broad blend of 50% Pinot Noir bringing depth, body and delicious spicy and toasty layers. Lemon-green in colour. The inviting nose has creamy fruit, strawberry, blood orange, dried flowers, baking spices and crunchy red apple. A fine toastiness emerges stronger with time in the glass. Friendly, fleshy and round lightweight palate. This will also reward further cellaring. Sublime in magnum. Dosage 8g/l”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Medium-deep lemon colour. Stylish, toasty and leesy nose. Lovely gunpowdery touch. Rather sweet palate but still in balance. Long, linear, succulent, finely focused palate. Super-stylish. This champagne has improved tremendously over the last years. Now it can sometimes challenge even Charles Heidsieck Brut Réserve. Outstanding in magnum.”

name: Lanson Extra Age Blanc de Blancs

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “With this wine my notes have varied significantly and one factor, no doubt, is its clear glass bottle allowing light taint to spoil it easily. Now, after having been on the markets for a few years already, the inaugural cuvée (05, 04, 03) is starting to show evolution and a mellow side of itself. Its nose is rather advanced with vanilla, baked apple and nutty notes but the palate is still very fresh and tight bringing contrast to it. This one has two ripe vintages in it, which comes across strongly but the 2004 brings a welcome addition of freshness. ”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Fine filigree texture. Competent and not sweet. Pretty good for an NV. Though it fades a little fast.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“100% Chardonnay. Seven years' ageing on lees. Disgorged December 2014. Dosage 3 g/l.
Tasted blind. Greenish deep straw. Creamy, lively nose. Fairly high dosage. I was going to guess Comtes until I saw that it wasn’t in the line-up! Slightly pinched finish. But then a peacock’s tail. The richest of these wines. 
Drink 2014-2023”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“100% Chardonnay in a special walled, so early-ripening, eighteenth-century vineyard in Reims. Part of it was planted in 1962 and part in 1986 after the frosts of 1985. What happened to these grapes before Clos Lanson was bottled separately to celebrate Philippe Bejot’s acquisition of Lanson in 2006? They went into vintage and Black Label. Fermented in pièces from Burgundy and 300-litre casks from Argonne.
Smoky nose. So distinctive! A bit like Laphroaig malt whisky! The oak still rather marks it but Hervé claims it’s ideal to drink now. Good acidity but there are definite oak overlays. Fruit is a tad weak for the moment, but should come out from behind the oak eventually. Good saline quality. Again, not one of the most intense on the finish.
Drink 2020-2030”

reviews.author: Antonio Galloni
reviews.note: “The 2006 Clos Lanson is bright, focused and exceptionally pure. Veins of underlying acidity and chalkiness give the 2006 its super-distinctive, saline-driven personality. Lemon peel, white flowers, chalk and white pepper develop in the glass, adding further dimensions of nuance. With time in the glass, the 2006 acquires lovely textural brilliance, but it remains tense, crystalline and absolutely impeccable in its purity. The aromatics could use a bit more finesse and freshness, but otherwise this is a solid debut. Clos Lanson is fermented entirely in barrel, but the oak is very nicely integrated. Disgorged December, 2014.”

reviews.author: Stephan Reinhardt
reviews.note: “From the immured one-hectare vineyard on the top of the hill, which also harbors the cellar of Champagne Lanson that dates back into the 18th century, the 2006 Clos Lanson is 100% first press Chardonnay from a very fine, chalky soil. It was fermented and aged in Argonne oak until spring 2007 (no malolactic fermentation), and disgorged after seven and a half years on the lees in December 2014 as Brut Nature with a dosage of three grams per liter. This bright yellow-golden colored prestige Champagne offers a brilliant nose of pure and ripe Chardonnay, along with delicate chalky flavors. Full and round on the palate, with a nice freshness and purity, this is a very elegant and well-balanced Blanc de Blancs. it has an aromatic as well as clear, fresh and mineral finish. This very first release has a very good length and characteristic mineral taste, with iodine notes along with ripe fruit and vanilla brioche flavors in the finish. This is a great new entry in the Lanson portfolio and it will improve with age. Total production is 7,870 serially numbered bottles.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“A new bottling on me in a broad, straight-sided flask from a single plot in Reims next to the cellars. 100% Chardonnay. Disgorged December 2014. 
Pale golden straw. Impressive aromatic completeness and integration on the nose – although one is hit by Lanson’s trademark high acidity on the palate. Very firm and still quite chewy. Tastes pretty youthful and aggressively frothy. I’d hold on to this for quite a while. Embryonic. 12%”

reviews.author: Michael Edwards
reviews.note:
“Generous fruit from the weathered chalk site is enhanced by a bright acidity, triggering mineral complexities. So delicious, tout en plaisir. The mineral imprint makes it a great match for ocean fish, especially turbot. A lovely surprise from the warm walled clos.
”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Rich golden colour. Highly expressive nose with tropical fruit, smoky layers sweet brioche and spicy vanilla aromas and finely integrated note of high-quality oak. Voluptuous, round, fleshy palate that is mouth-filling at first until the fine, zesty acidity kicks in and lifts the palate. The finish is minerality driven, fresh and succulent, emphasizing fruit purity. Great intensity and length.”

name: Pierre Gimonnet et Fils Millesime de Collection Vieilles Vignes de Chardonnay

reviews.author: Antonio Galloni
reviews.note: “The 2006 Brut Millésime de Collection Vieilles Vignes de Chardonnay (Magnum) is powerful, masculine and also a touch austere, but offers tremendous thrust and overall intensity. This is an especially large-scaled, creamy old-vine Champagne from Gimonnet. From magnum it should drink well for another decade or so. The Vieilles Vignes de Chardonnay emerges from parcels in Cramant and Chouilly (both Grand Cru villages) and Cuis, a 1er Cru village. Dosage is 5 grams per liter. Disgorged: January 2016.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Beautiful deep orange and copper toned colour. Evolved, soft, toasty nose with depth. Ripe cherry fruit, gentle spiciness. Quite winey, clean fruit and evolved style. Velvety texture and really harmonious character. A consistently great effort with the maceration method. Always a delight. I have also grown to be a great fan of the magnum, which ages in a grand fashion developing great winey qualities and Burgundian notions. ”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Bright salmon in colour, with orange tones, this wine is produced by the maceration method using Pinot Noirs from 10 Montagne de Reims villages, including Ambonnay, Bouzy, Louvois and Tours-sur-Marne. The beautifully expressive nose oozes Pinot Noir's sweet and spicy strawberry and blood orange fruit. Laurent-Perrier truly does master the maceration method of making rosé, achieving an amazing textural silkiness and structural tension without ever showing too much tannin or bitterness. This is truly one of Champagne's most unique premium non-vintage rosés, and ageworthy, too. I love how, with time, it starts to show a wilder side of itself, with lovely dark, spicy tones and sous-bois undernotes.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“There are no clues about disgorgement date or base vintage on the label – I couldn't even spot a lot number – but Nick Baker of The Finest Bubble kindly provided the lot code of the current cuvée – LP53UK35219E – and managed to persuade the chef de cave to divulge the background to it. This particular cuvée of the famous rosé champagne in the flask bottle is based on 2013. It's made from Pinot exclusively from 10 of the finest villages including Ambonnay, Bouzy, Louvois, Aÿ and the house's home patch of Tours-sur-Marne. It also includes 15% of reserve wine back to 2010 and spends all of 5.5 years on the lees, much longer than most NV rosés. Disgorged in September 2019 with a dosage of 10 g/l. They cold-macerate the grapes for two to three days, depending on the year, with the aim of extracting red-berry fruit flavours specifically rather than being concerned about the colour.
Pretty deep intensity of a colour that looks like pale tomato juice. Rose-petal aromas. Pretty aggressive mousse and light tannins on the end. This is quite an assertive pink champagne. It's not going to keep quiet as you enjoy your Valentine's dinner but may do a certain amount of interrupting. Red-berry fruit certainly in evidence before the tannins. Not my personal favourite style but it's certainly true to the ordained style and a lot of care goes into making it.
Drink 2021 – 2024”

reviews.author: Josh Reynolds
reviews.note: “Vivid orange-pink. An expressive, spice-accented bouquet evokes fresh raspberry, orange pith, white flowers and ginger, with a hint of rhubarb adding an earthy flourish. Sappy and broad in the mouth, offering intense red fruit and bitter citrus flavors underscored by chalky mineral and white pepper notes. Rich yet lively rosé with excellent closing thrust and floral persistence.”

reviews.author: Richard Hemming MW
reviews.note: “Light, simple red fruit, perky and tart. Precious little flavour development on the palate though. (RH)”

reviews.author: Stephen Tanzer
reviews.note: “Bright orange-pink. Toasty strawberry and raspberry aromas are accented by iodine, floral oils and dusty minerals. Broad and supple in texture, with sappy red berry and blood orange flavors supported by a firm spine of minerality. Finishes spicy, silky and long, with a late rose pastille note adding an exotic twist.”

reviews.author: Connoisseurs Guide
reviews.note: “Elegant and fruity at the same time with a quick invitation from bright, pure cherryish notes and then filled out handsomely by whiffs of chalky soils and well-integrated, rich and uplifting yeast-driven scents, this wine manages to be both vigorous and layered at one and the same time. Its bubbles are insistent, finely carved and add to the early sensations of lightness and energy yet also carry the wine long into a balanced, refined finish. And its latter palate grip is exactly what one should expect from the genre. While service with light foods would be our first choice, this one has the beauty to stand alone.”

reviews.author: Tamlyn Currin
reviews.note:
“First released in 1968. Laurent-Perrier wanted to show that rosé could be a serious wine. 100% Pinot Noir – unusually not a blend of white and red wines. Crushed for 36 hours. RS 8 g/l. 
Wild-salmon pink. Raspberries, freshness, a hint of tarragon on the nose. Lacy mousse. Tart raspberries, peppery green herbs, a small but intense sweet-salty-dark-sharp note of balsamic vinegar. Juicy yet composed. Dry. (TC)”

reviews.author: Wine Spectator
reviews.note: “Shows fine balance, with a vibrant tanginess to the flavors of black currant, strawberry, licorice and candied ginger. Features a fine, creamy bead, revealing a lasting note of smoky mineral on the finish. Drink now through 2018. Tasted twice, with consistent notes.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note: “Very pretty pale salmon. Extremely, exuberantly fruity (as opposed to fine).  This comes in the smartest conceivable pink box. Dead classy. Suggestions of strawberries.  Nice level of fizz but not one of the most sophisticated pink champagnes in my view.”

name: Lanson Noble Cuvee Blanc de Blancs Brut Millesime

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“70% Chardonnay, 30% Pinot Noir. Disgorged June 2016. Dosage 6 g/l.
Light nose and lots of both apparent sweetness and acidity. Not yet married but certainly ambitious. A tad astringent on the finish. A little simple but perhaps it will take on more interest. Tense but promising. Very lacy and fine with real breadth of exotic flavour.
Drink 2018-2028”

reviews.author: Decanter
reviews.note: “Bright and clear with a gentle effervescence of fine bubbles. The nose shows attractive almond, lemon and floral notes. The palate is crispy dry and elegant with granny smith apples, medium toasty notes and good minerality.”

reviews.author: Jancis Robinson MW
reviews.note:
“Disgorged June 2015. RS 6 g/l.  Supplied by Lanson UK.
Tasted blind. Great energy. Real interest on the nose and pretty high acid still on the palate (which should have led me to Lanson). A little astringent on the end. Slightly loose textured. And not that long. But it improved in the glass. According to The Finest Bubble’s scorekeeper, I gave this wine 18 but I was too busy to keep a record of it on my laptop.”

reviews.author: Stephan Reinhardt
reviews.note: “Lanson's 2002 Noble Cuvée Blanc des Blancs Millésime Brut is 100% Chardonnay from Grand Cru villages. It is a rich, ripe and round Blanc de Blancs that combines its smooth opulence with freshness, elegance, finesse and purity. Excellent and still on its way.”

reviews.author: Essi Avellan MW
reviews.note: “Tight, sulphuric smoky-mineral nose with tropical fruit underneath. Firm, zesty, well focused palate with long succulent length with a hefty yet balanced dosage. Highly youthful still. Hopefully the reductive sulphuric note will settle.”
